triples.evidence: diagnostic performance is shaped by two things: the reader’s skill and the technology’s power.
This is exactly what the ROC curve captures - the combined effect of technology and human expertise.
triples.o: combined effect of technology and human expertise

evidence: Diagnostic performance is shaped by two things: the reader's skill and the technology's power.
Better imaging systems reduce overlap, but equally important is the ability of the radiologist to interpret the image correctly.
The same scan might lead to different conclusions depending on who reads it.
A highly trained radiologist can extract subtle discriminating features that others may miss.

Not every doctor reads images with the same skill. Some physicians, with years of training and experience, can clearly separate diseased from non-diseased cases. For them, the two distributions hardly overlap, and their ROC curve bends sharply toward the upper-left corner - that's excellent diagnostic power.
Diagnostic performance is shaped by two things: the reader’s skill and the technology’s power.
Better imaging systems reduce overlap, but equally important is the ability of the radiologist to interpret the image correctly.
The ROC curve captures - the combined effect of technology and human expertise.

triples.evidence: Diagnostic performance is shaped by two things: the reader’s skill and the technology’s power.
